data.name: Elementary Cellular Automata - Part 1
data.description:
Elementary Cellular Automata - Part 1
In this Kata you will take a first step to help work with very basic Cellular Automata.
These articles explain the concepts of Cellular Automata.
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ElementaryCellularAutomaton.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton#Elementary_cellular_automata
In particular for this Kata you should see how rules are classified and how to determine a cell state based on its neighbors. For now we won't even worry about iterating generations.
This first step is simple.
Your function will return the state that a cell will take based on a given nearest neighbors pattern and a given rule.
The two possible states of the returned cell are represented by '0' and '1'.
The pattern of neighbors is represented as a string. For example "101".
The rule is represented by an integer. For example 188.
The input pattern will always be 3 characters long and contain only '0's and '1's.
The rule will always be a value 0 to 255.
Example: Given a neighbor pattern of "101" and given rule 30, return '0'.
Given a neighbor pattern of "101" and given rule 188, return '1'.
Given a neighbor pattern of "111" and given rule 102, return '0'.
